<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 121, 636, 145]]<|/det|>
# Cambridge International AS & A Level  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 170, 195, 201]]<|/det|>
CANDIDATE NAME  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 222, 175, 250]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[620, 220, 720, 250]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[735, 210, 905, 255]]<|/det|>  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 276, 232, 292]]<|/det|>
## MATHEMATICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[832, 277, 905, 292]]<|/det|>
9709/42  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 301, 245, 316]]<|/det|>
Paper 4 Mechanics  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[732, 301, 905, 316]]<|/det|>
February/March 2025  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[760, 325, 905, 341]]<|/det|>
1 hour 15 minutes  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 355, 393, 370]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the question paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 393, 400]]<|/det|>
You will need: List of formulae (MF19)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 419, 222, 434]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 270, 450]]<|/det|>
Answer all questions.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 450, 760, 466]]<|/det|>
Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 466, 808, 482]]<|/det|>
Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 482, 562, 497]]<|/det|>
Write your answer to each question in the space provided.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 498, 480, 512]]<|/det|>
Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 513, 358, 527]]<|/det|>
Do not write on any bar codes.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 528, 868, 559]]<|/det|>
If additional space is needed, you should use the lined page at the end of this booklet; the question number or numbers must be clearly shown.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 560, 485, 574]]<|/det|>
You should use a calculator where appropriate.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 575, 880, 605]]<|/det|>
You must show all necessary working clearly; no marks will be given for unsupported answers from a calculator.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 606, 856, 636]]<|/det|>
Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place for angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 636, 777, 652]]<|/det|>
Where a numerical value for the acceleration due to gravity \((g)\) is needed, use \(10 \text{m} \text{s}^{- 2}\) .  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 680, 213, 695]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 696, 730, 728]]<|/det|>
The total mark for this paper is 50. The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 92, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[307, 81, 687, 255]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 275, 920, 311]]<|/det|>
Three coplanar forces of magnitudes \(40\mathrm{N}\) , \(30\mathrm{N}\) and \(X\mathrm{N}\) act at a point in the directions shown in the diagram.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 320, 640, 341]]<|/det|>
Given that the forces are in equilibrium, find the values of \(\theta\) and \(X\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 322, 917, 339]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 75, 97, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 75, 920, 144]]<|/det|>
A cyclist is travelling along a straight horizontal road at a speed of \(4 \mathrm{~m} \mathrm{~s}^{- 1}\) when she passes a point \(O\). She accelerates at a constant rate for a distance of \(42 \mathrm{~m}\), reaching a speed of \(V \mathrm{~m} \mathrm{~s}^{- 1}\). She maintains the speed of \(V \mathrm{~m} \mathrm{~s}^{- 1}\) for \(50 \mathrm{~m}\) and then decelerates at \(2 \mathrm{~m} \mathrm{~s}^{- 2}\) before coming to rest. The distance travelled while decelerating is \(16 \mathrm{~m}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 156, 144, 174]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 156, 312, 174]]<|/det|>
Find the value of \(V\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 156, 920, 174]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 490, 186, 509]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 490, 781, 509]]<|/det|>
Find the total time for which she is in motion from the instant that she passes \(O\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 492, 920, 511]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 94, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 72, 450, 89]]<|/det|>
An aeroplane is flying at a constant speed.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 102, 146, 120]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 102, 920, 135]]<|/det|>
The aeroplane is flying horizontally. The aeroplane's engines are producing a constant power of \(5500\mathrm{kW},\) and the aeroplane experiences a constant horizontal resistance force of \(25\mathrm{kN}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 149, 405, 168]]<|/det|>
Find the speed of the aeroplane.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 149, 920, 168]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 460, 186, 477]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 460, 920, 508]]<|/det|>
The aeroplane then ascends \(300\mathrm{m}\) in \(50\mathrm{s},\) while maintaining the same speed. The resistance force is no longer constant, and the work done against the resistance force in ascending the \(300\mathrm{m}\) is \(270000\mathrm{kJ}.\) The mass of the aeroplane is \(60000\mathrm{kg}.\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 520, 554, 540]]<|/det|>
Find the average power of the aeroplane's engines.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 520, 920, 539]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 92, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[346, 78, 650, 255]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 268, 920, 336]]<|/det|>
Two particles \(A\) and \(B\) have masses \(0.3 \mathrm{kg}\) and \(0.1 \mathrm{kg}\) respectively. The particles are attached to the ends of a light inextensible string. The string passes over a fixed smooth pulley, and the particles hang vertically below the pulley. Both particles are initially at a height of \(x \mathrm{m}\) above horizontal ground (see diagram). The system is released from rest.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 348, 146, 367]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 348, 667, 368]]<|/det|>
Find the tension in the string and the acceleration of the particles.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 349, 920, 368]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 71, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
During the subsequent motion, \(B\) does **not** reach the pulley. When \(A\) reaches the ground, it comes to rest.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 119, 143, 136]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 117, 784, 137]]<|/det|>
Given that the greatest height of \(B\) above the ground is \(1.2 \text{m}\), find the value of \(x\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 119, 920, 136]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 67, 133, 85]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[222, 78, 776, 134]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 149, 920, 220]]<|/det|>
Three particles \(P, Q\) and \(R\), of masses \(0.6 \text{kg}\), \(0.4 \text{kg}\) and \(0.8 \text{kg}\) respectively, are at rest in a straight line on a smooth horizontal plane. The distance from \(P\) to \(Q\) is \(3 \text{m}\), and the distance from \(Q\) to \(R\) is also \(3 \text{m}\) (see diagram). \(P\) is projected directly towards \(Q\) with speed \(3 \text{m s}^{-1}\). After \(P\) and \(Q\) collide, \(P\) continues to move in the same direction with speed \(1.5 \text{m s}^{-1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 230, 146, 249]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 230, 458, 250]]<|/det|>
Find the speed of \(Q\) after the collision.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 231, 918, 250]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 603, 662, 622]]<|/det|>
In the subsequent collision between \(Q\) and \(R\), these particles coalesce.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 634, 146, 653]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 634, 616, 653]]<|/det|>
Find the speed of the combined particle after this collision.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 635, 918, 653]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 144, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 71, 920, 104]]<|/det|>
Find the time that it takes from when \(P\) is initially projected until the instant at which \(P\) collides with the combined particle.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 85, 920, 103]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 92, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[245, 81, 751, 230]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 241, 920, 293]]<|/det|>
A block of mass \(12\mathrm{kg}\) is placed on a rough plane inclined at an angle of \(\alpha\) to the horizontal, where \(\alpha = \tan^{-1} 0.5\). A force of \(X \mathrm{N}\) is applied to the block, directly up the plane (see diagram). The coefficient of friction between the block and the plane is \(\mu\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 305, 146, 323]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 305, 450, 324]]<|/det|>
It is given that \(\mu = 0.15\) and \(X = 20\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 335, 764, 355]]<|/det|>
Find the time that it takes for the block to move \(2 \text{m}\) down the plane from rest.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 336, 917, 355]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 146, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 918, 106]]<|/det|>
It is given instead that \(\mu \neq 0.15\) and that when \(X = 10\), the block is on the point of moving down the plane.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 119, 918, 138]]<|/det|>
Find the value of \(\mu\) and the value of \(X\) for which the block is on the point of moving **up** the plane.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 135, 918, 153]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 74, 96, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 920, 126]]<|/det|>
A particle moves in a straight line. The velocity \(\nu \mathrm{m} \mathrm{s}^{- 1}\) of the particle \(t \mathrm{s}\) after leaving a fixed point \(O\) is given by \(\nu = k(20 + pt - 6t^2)\), where \(k\) and \(p\) are constants. The acceleration of the particle at \(t = 1\) is \(42 \mathrm{m} \mathrm{s}^{- 2}\), and the displacement of the particle from \(O\) at \(t = 1\) is \(93 \mathrm{m}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 139, 146, 158]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 138, 386, 158]]<|/det|>
Show that \(k = 3\) and \(p = 26\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 139, 920, 158]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 146, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 72, 920, 104]]<|/det|>
Find the distance moved by the particle between the time at which its acceleration is zero and the time at which its velocity is zero.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 85, 920, 103]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 102, 920, 135]]<|/det|>
If you use the following page to complete the answer to any question, the question number must be clearly shown.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[433, 73, 562, 88]]<|/det|>
